reviewText: Curse of Mermos is a truly free game. You play top down fighting waves of enemy's and collecting treasure and artifacts to further your objectives. The game is simple and challenging and I do enjoy it.  I have no qualms about recommending it as it is a truly free game, its super simple, and really the only thing that I could even consider being a negative is that you will be better off playing it with a controller.\n\nSo if your in for a good free game, and want some challenge try the Curse of Mermos.
voteText: 80 of 105 people (76%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: Fun little game. Nothing too fancy, but it's exactly what it advertises. If you have an hour to kill and like this kind of game I would reccommend it.\n\nEdit: after looking at some of the negative reviews, I have no idea where they are coming from. I went back and tried to clip through all of the walls and gates and couldn't, and I played the first 15 or so waves with the mouse and keyboard and it's fine. Haters gonna hate. *shrugs*
voteText: 39 of 45 people (87%) found this review helpful 6 people found this review funny

reviewText:
The game is fun, free, but most importantly, very difficult.

As you progress through the game, you will encounter more and more difficult enemies. For example, an enemy you can't hit, until it slams it's shield onto the ground. However, once those same shield enemies clump together, it becomes very difficult to kill them. There are also enemies that heal their allies, two different ranged attackers, an enemy that rolls near you, in droves, and blows up, an enemy that throws flame AoE at you, and small critters.

The game became very fustrating towards the end, which was at wave 29-30. You are expected to retrieve 3,000 souls, which is a lot. You will be engulfed in flames, shield slammers, enemy healers, and lots of explosive enemies.

I was terribly, terribly destroyed and I ended up quitting on my 5th try on completing the wave, where I must retrieve the 3,000 souls. I have yet to complete the game.

I do not recommend this game to casuals, but those who are willing to experience a game that will challenge their gamer minds.

reviewText:
This game is really fun and challenging, a true indie gem. You play top-down, fighting waves of enemies. New enemies appear every few rounds, making it more challenging to finish a round.

There are really no downsides that I could find, the combat and the abilities are just in-depth enough to keep the game intriguing and fun until the end, and the controls and UI were very fluid and nice. Another thing that I really liked was the charming graphics. They were pretty yet maintaned a cartoonish feel.

10/10 would recommend.
voteText: 28 of 41 people (68%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Quick Review of the game I've played so far.

Pros:
It was challenging at first.
It is controller compatible
Nice scenery for a free game.

Cons:
It was repetetive.
It is not optimized for keyboards.
Grinding souls is tedious.
You can clip through walls like a knife through warm butter.

Analysis:
The game starts you off in the tomb. That's it. There's dialogue, but nobody reads anymore. (amirite)
Apparently you're supposed to help this Mummy guy, Ebo, lift the Curse of Mermos (GASP the game title!)
You fight ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. Cool. But that's about it. Sure there's a shop and all, but there's only those 5 items. Two of the items aren't even items.
The glyphs are alright IMO. They add a little bit of risk to the game while still adding worthwhile benefits such as life regen or more health at the cost of agility.
Cool ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. So, lets get down to the gameplay. If you're using a mouse and keyboard... So sorry. Controllers are fine! They work great with this game and almost every review besides mine has the controller influence it.

I'm gonna get down to the other stuff. Clipping.
I'm not talking about Oh I can go through one of the pillars in the main room" clipping. I'm talking game breaking clips.
You can go through the wall behind Ebo at anytime. It's literally not there. You can go through any gate you want (closed or not) with these clips
date:
but the cost is you can't continue your game any further. It will literally keep you in the room you are supposed to be in forever (whether or not all the enemies are killed).
The game is solid until you screw up with one roll and end up through a gate you aren't supposed to be behind.

Next thing. Saving.
There is none. I quit (after i broke my own game testing the clipping and such) and restarted
recommended:
expecting to resume from where I had left off.
No. That is not a thing. You WILL have to restart if you quit.

Conclusion:
The game
voteText: is solid. Great for controllers

reviewText:
It's... okay... but overall, nothing in it stands out all to be picked out as excellent.
I have not played this game to completion, but that's mostly because it became boring after not too long.

Pros:
Decent and fitting graphics.
Small skill curve for immersion.
Progression long enough for several hours of gameplay.

Cons:
Semi-awkward control scheme.
Movement feels slightly unoptimized.
Bland gameplay - too repetitive, not enough to repeat.
Not very large maps, or rather one large-ish map.

reviewText: I went through and played the game until wave 29 and just couldn't take it anymore. I was having fun at first but by the time I got to wave 11 I started getting very aggrivated, it's not hard or anything just annoying. Enemies spawn right on top of you so you have to constantly roll to not get hit, this is not good game design. I appreciate that you guys released it for free so I can't really complain I guess but I found myself asking When is this going to be over"? I don't mean that in a good way either
date: I was genuinely annoyed by playing this. There is no point to having melee attacks at all in this either
recommended: you take way too much damage when attempting to do so and I ended up just using the bow instead. By the time you get the charge shot you realize just how broken the combat is as well
hoursPlayed: since you can't aim with the second thumbstick you have to use the lock on system which you called strafing for some ungodly reason. How about calling it what it is instead. I didn't know I could lock on until the sixth wave because of it when you decided to put a tutorial message about it in the upper right corner of the screen. You can't call those videos in the beginning a tutorial either
voteText: they just show you gameplay with no real description of whats going on. It's a good effort for a student project but if you're going to be doing game design when you get out of school there are a lot of things you need to take into consideration from this project. I honestly do not see a point in this game being released on steam other than to show off your hard work which is probably just copied and pasted from source that is already available on the web. Anyway
helpfulPercent: back to the lock on system
votesHelpful: you'll miss more shots than you'll hit due to having to use it and since you can't aim without moving it makes things much more difficult than it should be. I don't mean difficult as in hard either I mean controlwise this game is garbage. In the later levels you'll find yourself rolling around the entire map until all of the enemies spawn and then leading them single file into your charge shots... this is not fun. If the devs go back and fix a lot of the things in this game for the steam release then I could definitely recommend this but as it stands with the shoddy mechanics and not being able to save your progress for later then I can't. The game isn't very long
votesTotal: two hours at the most but having to play all the way through in one sitting feels like a chore with the mechanics the way they are now. With all that said
votesFunny: I still say good work to the devs because this is great for a school project but I just feel like there should be more to the game than there is for it to really gain traction here on steam. A for effort

reviewText:
I spent a couple of hours with the game (outside of steam). And first and foremost, it is highly recommended that you try this with a gamepad (It seems most bad reviews are related to it being hard to play on keyboard and mouse).  Once you get that out of  the way though, you are left with a simple, yet very fun game. It has nice progression, and the combat yet simple is a very good example of an action rpg  dungeon crawler of sort, it is tricky and the monsters AI is good.

It is totally worth picking up and playing, A bang for your buck, but since it's free that's even better, no?

Highly recommended, if anything but to support great indie devs.

reviewText:
It's a free basic hack & slash game. It is simple, it is free and it is exactly what it presents to be.

However, even though this game is free (saying this for the third time), it just seems....it lacks the desire to keep on playing the game. Graphics are outdated, but the gameplay is solid. The story doesn't really matter (as there is no true story behind it)

But I can not recommend this game. Not in the current state. Add more customisation. More classes? More weapons? More beasts to fight on, and perhaps different locations? I haven't played it a lot, true, but it just doesn't seem be worth my time. (too many other games)

If you are bored and want to play something"

reviewText:
Just a disclaimer before I start off, I did not play this game for 11 hours, I left it open by accident, but I did spend about 2 to 3 hours on this game and I am liked it although there are some things about it that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• me off.

So, basicly it has a strong resemblance to Spiral Knights, which is also a free to play game on steam, although this one is only a single player game,

The game puts you in the depth of probably a pyramid of some sorts, when you find yourself talking to a huge ghost of a mummy and helping it retreive 4 parts in order to bring it back to life (for some reason?), on your way you will fight some monsters, collect souls and artifacts, improved your character and in the end you will fight the big mummy you helped (again, for some reason...) bring back to life.

The game has some nice variety of enemies, although I do feel it should have some more types to it.
Your character has 2 types of weapons, a melee weapon (most likely a hammer) and a ranged weapon (most likely a crossbow). But, there is a big problem with these weapons, on the one hand, the melee weapon is too dangerous because you will need to keep your health as high as possible at all parts of the game and getting into your enemies face is not a smart idea what so ever, so it is greatly unrewarding and even punishing to mostly use a melee weapon. And on the other hand, the ranged weapon suffers greatly because of the aim system in the game, now you would think that you would aim by moving your mouse BUT NO you have to use a mechanic called STIFE" in order to aim

voteText: lets move aside that it would 99% only aim for the closest enemy

votesHelpful: which is so important when defeating enemies (especially healers) it just wanders around before you attack and shoots at a nearby wall. COOL.\n\nThis makes the game almost unbeatable
votesTotal: I do not see any point of having this stupid - ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• mechanic instead of aiming with your mouse. To add on that
votesFunny: THERE IS NO SAVE BUTTON. There are 30 stages in the game

column19: or even a better option would be to make you able to aim with your mouse.\nSecond thing is adding up a saving button
column20: or a checkpoint of some sorts (that saves your progress even if you exit the game).\nThird thing is I think this game should add a difficulty scale

reviewText:
Honest Review - Mostly Positive
Ok,

The positive things about it.

ITS FREE! Can't beat that, also, NO ADS, it is 100% free.
It's cute, it's got a great atmosphere. The music, sound effects, artwork. It all comes together to make a great little game. It plays almost exactly like Burn Zombie Burn, except with more technical enemies, and ALOT of running around. It has a great difficulty curve, and culminates in a very natural boss" encounter and puts all of your skills to use
date: I wish more games ended like this one
recommended: instead of using some weird cookie cutter boss that does not relate to your skills. I loved how the game makes you develop these natural strategies for dealing with the different enemies
hoursPlayed:
and I felt like I was definitely getting better at the game the longer I played it.

Neutral things
It took me about 90 minutes to beat
voteText: in one sitting. I died twice. I'm pretty good at twin stick shooters

there's nothing to do for 10 levels other than wail on enemies until the final boss.


Bad Things
The control scheme really needs some work. I played this using a PS4 controller

reviewText: This game is fun for the first few waves, but then they get boring. The waves become longer with the same four enimies and evey attack is nearly impoosible to dodge because they home or are to fast. But that's not a problem! The give so much health and potions, that it's nearly impossible to die! Weapons wise: there's two. They're both crappy. the melee weapon is near useless because you can't hit them with being hit yourself! And the enimies do about the same damage your hatchet does. The crossbow does near zero damage, but is the only good weapon! I find the most of the upgrades useless, and I find myself doing this: Roll, Roll, Shoot, Shoot Shoot, and repeat. FOR THE REST OF THE GAME!!! The story is creative, but cheesy and predictable. The protagonist has no flaws, and is complete nerd. Three fourths of all of the things he says are about ancient history and crap like that. The level you play in doesn't really capture the idea of a spooky tomb, and is small and compact. It should be a large open field, with hoards of enimes, instead of a small, ompact room with 100 enimies per wave that die in a few hits. To be honest, the description of the game given by the creators is crap. I got the game so I could play it with my friend, but I couldn't get the multiplayer option to function. In all, I give this game a 3/10. You might like it, but as it stands, I think it's bad. But that's an opinion.

reviewText:
This is a great game for everyone who like strategy fast paced games.

reviewText: Let's see, Let's see.... Ah, a review on, Curse of Mermos
date:
seems like a good idea.

Curse of Mermos, a game where you're a Young Archeoligist, where you come across the tomb of... Eto, Epo? I forget, anyways, It's pretty much a Game where you go through 31 Waves, the 31st being the final wave and you get Upgrades along the way. You also have to collect 4 Artifacts along the way, which triggers another wave, so don't get the item until ready. There are also two items of Value, Shards & Souls, Shard are used to purchase Glyphs that help you along the way, while Souls can be used to Purchase Potions and upgrades for your Axe, Bow, Speed, and Health.You have an Axe and a Bow, which are used to defend yourself. You can Roll around as well and this is where a Glitch comes in, if you upgrade your roll all the way, you can get into ANY area by rolling and I mean ANY AREA, you can roll through walls with this glitch as well, which can ruin the Gaming experience of this game. Let's switch to the topic of Mobs/Monsters, First we have Scarab Beetles, (GET IT CAUSE WE'RE IN THE EGYPTIAN TOMBS HUEHUEHUE) Skeletons, (Original/10) Warrior, (Pretty much there in the near to last waves) Suicide bombs, (Wait what.) Skeleton heads, (AGAIN WITH THE SKELETONS!) Fire Creatures, (FIRE, FIRE, FIREEEEE!) and the most annoying Mob/Monster, Healers. (I can't remember their names.)

Overall, the game gets a 4/10, the effort was minimal, and it needs more Variety.

reviewText: Extremely fun! Puts many expensive and disappointing games of the same genre to shame. The visuals are very nicely done, they have a great look and create a good sense of atmosphere. I would use an Xbox 360 PC controller (really, let's be honest here - these days, if you're a PC gamer and DON'T have a controller, Xbox or other, you're only hurting yourself!), the game is set up to use one and it works great. And as a nice bonus too, especially for a free game, the developers are amazing - I had an issue that prevented me from being able to play, reported it, less than an hour later it was fixed and I was having a blast. Now I call that BEYOND commendable! So all in all, I can't recommend this game highly enough. At this price, if you don't give it a try, you're mental!  ;)

reviewText:
Please note that this review is based on playing with a mouse + keyboard.
How this works with a controller might be a total different experience!


Those controls..

Basicly you aim with auto aim using shift. Tabbing it target after target, since you can't do it with the mouse and otherwise the only option to aim is with A, W, S, D. Next to that you have to spam the right mouse button to shoot single bolts (or melee up close with left button) a lot! especially at the beginning. Which again doesn't feel comfortable at all!

After about 40 minutes reaching wave 20+ some mobs came in wielding a shield and the only way to hit them is from behind. Which you have to do by waiting for an attack, quickly run behind them and hit. But then I got 4 of them at once, and its practicly impossible to properly hit them without being hit by them, due to the clumsy controls.

It eventually made me ragequit the game, not because I couldn't beat it. But because my fingers hurt like hell of the shift + mouse click spam and the frustration it brought. I for sure won't touch this game again, the idea is neat. But the controls make this game practicly unplayable.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xtimarPWTYk

reviewText:
TL;DR at the bottom.
First off I enjoyed the game for what it is, a neat little hack'n slash game with rpg-ish elements. But the cons outweigh the pros way too much to actually recommend this game.

Here's why:
- No explanation on how things came to be. The first part of the narrative is missing. You are basically a random guy with two OP AF ancient weapons, a hammer and a crossbow and you lay waste to hundres of scarabs, skeletons and whatnot to help out your best homie Ebo for whatever reasons. Cool story brah.
- Progress is not saved: once you quit, you quit and everything starts all over again. Unless you plan to finish the game in one sitting ragequitting to someday come back to this game is not an option.
- Controller use is recommended because the mouse and keyboard is not fully supported / was meant to be played with controller. Sounds fair(?). Curious enough, the right control stick was not used at all in this kind of game it could / should have to allow some sort of free aim while fighting with the crossbow.
- At the end of each wave you have a little cheer that is around one second long. Sounds short but it's pretty annoying if that's the reason you miss out on some souls (currency dropt by enemies) and you are ~1-5 souls short for your new upgrade.
- The upgrade system is basic. Very very basic. Weapons and health upgrades have an early milestone which unlocks a charge attack for weapons and the ability to magically carry more health potions.... Other than that there is nothing but increased damage. Glyphs are interesting yet you will automatically choose the one without a malus. Glyphs with a bonus AND a malus are risky and the reward is not all to clear in it's actual worth.
- As you already have two OP weapons, there is no need for other items. No loot for you. And no experience. So it's a hackn' slash game with rpg-ish elements. But 100% purebred free game (and the crowd goes mild!).

But to be fair a little pro aspects as well:
- Starting screen allows you to choose the keybinding, graphics (basic option with no explanation) and the monitor. Neato.
- It runs smoothly and I experienced no crashes, but it could be because of the low gametime. Who knows.
- Sounds are decent as well as the music.
- No annoying ads at all. like / favourite / subscribe
- While the game itself looks pretty basic it is very much unforgiving if you do not use the talents and options available to you. Prepare to Die Edition.


Loveletter to the devs:I would like to see a story, an introduction and a narrative. A personality for the character you are playing and a motivation. Improved upgrade system both souls and shard one. More options in the options (kek), for audio / colourblind / other languages / damage numbers. The implementation of the right stick for free aim while using a weapon. Combination of moves (roll + melee / range) for another new move. Visible upgrades to the weapons and character to counter balance the no items agenda for the character progression.
Character creation(?): male / female, face, hair. I noticed that the dude has brown hair in the icon but runs around with a blonde wig ingame. Leaderboards. If you make the decision to stay on steam and release new games, make sure you implement steam as well (trading cards and achievements). It gives new room, for example challenges and such.
The option to run the game in windowed fullscreen. And most important an option to actually save progress.

That's about it and I would like to try a 2.0 version of it in the future.

If you read through this brick and you're not convinced or take me for a dirty ol' liar you better check yourself and give the game a try before you wreck yourself... punk.





TL;DR: Your mom says hi.

reviewText:
IF YOU DON'T LIKE READING LONG PASSAGES, SKIP TO THE BOTTOM FOR A SIMPLIFIED REVIEW
Curse of Mermos is one of those games you pick up to experiment with for one session, then forget about it the following week. It's in no way memorable or fun, seeing as the game just recycles itself over and over until you want to do your head in with a rock. Thank god this game is free; this review would have been a lot angrier if it wasn't.

You will only see 7-8 different types of enemies throughout the whole 30 wave game. You've got generic spiders, generic skeletons, generic skeleton  heads , generic mummies, and generic healers; each with only one flimsy attack to defend themselves with. Every enemy gets used so many times that you really have to hope and pray for somthing original to pop up.

Another thing to question is the game's complete lack of substance. The entirety of it is rinse and repeat: finish a couple waves, retrieve a trinket. Upgrade some stuff, finish more waves, retrieve a trinket. This repeats  FOUR TIMES  until you're left with nothing but filler waves to make the game seem longer. Every wave up to wave 20 is extremely easy; there's never any need to use melee whatsoever (even when the game tells you You won't escape the tomb without using melee" in a tip). All you really need to upgrade is agility
recommended: and bow damage. After getting the fourth trinket
hoursPlayed: the waves are literally  THE EXACT SAME . I quit the game at round 28 because I literally became sad every time a new wave was ready to be played. It's  that  repetitive and boring. The enviornment doesn't even change for christ's sake; you're stuck in the same cluster of confined spaces for an eternity.\n\nBefore I keep ranting on and on
voteText: let me just simplify all of this: Curse of Mesmos is beyond bland. Every enemy is recycled to oblivion
helpfulPercent: the story that the game tries to pull off is non-existant
votesHelpful: some attacks never even need to be used at all (despite the game saying so)
votesTotal: and if you don't have a controller
votesFunny: you're screwed. This game is not worth your time in the slightest.\n\n"

reviewText: I was looking for a game to play when I was extremely bored with all the multiplayers and I stumbled upon this game, Curse of Mermos. I was hoping to spend my leisure playing an interesting hack'n'slash game. I expected this game to be as superb as Path of Exile and I can tell you I was mistaken. If you are looking for a decent hack'n'slash game, well... keep looking. This game doesn't support PC gamers who don't have gamepads and use their mouse + keyboard combination instead. It's very hard to aim and thus the enemies don't yield even during the very first levels. The plot doesn't seem to be clear for me, you feel like the entire game starts in the middle of a tangled story you don't have a clue about. It's literally like finishing someone's unfinished game. Although the game appears to be a pleasant boredom-killer, it's more of a terrible attempt of the authors to come to existence in the games industry. I'm sorry to say so, but this game is a disaster to say the least. I don't recommend it at all.

reviewText: Curse of Mermos is very simple and yet very hard: battle various minions and continue to survive each wave, upgrading your stats as you go. reviewText:
Curse of Mermos is a free to play, indie hack and slash game. It is an okay game. I don't dislike it, it's just that, it's one of those games you play when you are bored. Yeah.

Curse of Mermos, (I will call it CoM), is a game where you fight of waves of monsters, and buy items to help you better fight off these waves. The game is set in the tomb of Ebo, and your only weapons are the Hammer of Horus amd the Crossbow of Neith. You unlock/upgrade your ablities with souls, witch drop off enemies, (This sounds like Dark Souls). As you play, the waves of monsters get harder and harder, with new enemies being introduced a lot. Also, there is no saving feature, so if you exit the game, or go to the main menu, then you have to start all over again. I find this really stupid. You don't even get your upgrades back!

Overall, this is a mediocre game at best. I know some people may like it, and that is fine. It was an okay game. I just don't personally recommend this game to people.
